basics.name: Ana M. Palacio Castro
basics.label: Assistant Scientist
basics.summary: A biologist interested how ocean warming, acidification, diseases, and pollution affect corals. I identify environmental and genetic factors that promote more resistant corals that could survive in our fast changing world.

education.thesis: Abiotic controls on endosymbiotic algal communities and their implications for coral bleaching susceptibility and recovery.
Comparison of methods for monitoring sessile benthic communities in “La Azufrada”, coral reef, Gorgona Island National Natural Park.

awards.title: Co-PI: Characterizing and forecasting coastal ecosystem responses to multiple stressors for management applications in South Florida
awards.awarder: National Ocean Service (NOS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)

awards.title: PI: High-replication assessment of the effects of poor water quality on South Florida coral health and susceptibility to Stony Coral Tissue Loss Disease
PI: Assessing the effects of environmental co-factors on SCTLD transmission and progression rates

publications.title: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.title: Coral reef resilience to thermal stress in the Eastern Tropical Pacific
Source location and food availability determine the growth response of Orbicella faveolata to climate change stressors

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).
